title-group.article-title: Ganglions of the hand and wrist: determinants of treatment choice

contrib.aff: Department of Orthopaedic Surgery, Massachusetts General Hospital, Boston, MA, USA
Department of Behavioral Medicine, Massachusetts General Hospital, Boston, MA, USA
Department of Orthopaedic Surgery, Massachusetts General Hospital, Boston, MA, USA

author-notes.corresp: David Ring MD PhD, Department of Orthopaedic Surgery, Massachusetts General Hospital, Yawkey Center, Suite 2100, 55 Fruit Street, Boston, MA 02114, USA Email: dring@partners.org

permissions.copyright-holder: The British Society for Surgery of the Hand

abstract.p: The aim of this study was to determine whether psychological factors (depression, catastrophic thinking, and pain anxiety) and pain intensity are associated with choice of operative treatment. Ninety new patients with a ganglion cyst on their hand or wrist completed psychological questionnaires (Pain Catastrophizing Scale, Pain Anxiety Symptoms Scale, and Center for the Epidemiological Study of Depression instrument) and an ordinal measure of pain intensity. After a minimum of 4 months, patients were contacted to determine if they chose operative treatment, to rate their pain intensity, and to complete the Disabilities of the Arm, Shoulder, and Hand questionnaire. Younger patients were more likely to choose operative treatment. Psychological factors were associated with pain intensity at enrolment, but not with treatment choice. Operative treatment did not result in less pain intensity or disability, or higher satisfaction compared with non-operative treatment.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: A ganglion is a benign synovial fluid-filled cyst associated with an articulation or tendon sheath (Gude and Morelli, 2008). Patients present with various symptoms such as pain, aesthetic concerns, spontaneous drainage, or a concern that the lump might be cancer (Dias et al., 2007; Westbrook et al., 2000). Some patients are satisfied with information alone, while others request surgery to remove the cyst. Psychological factors (such as pain anxiety, catastrophic thinking, and depression) increase symptoms and disability for a given pathology (Barsky AJ, 2004; Ring et al., 2004; Ring et al., 2005), and we wondered whether they influenced the decision to pursue operative treatment.

In this study, we tested the primary null hypothesis that there is no significant difference in pain intensity, catastrophic thinking, depression, pain anxiety at enrolment and disability, pain intensity, and patient satisfaction at final evaluation, between patients who elect operative versus non-operative treatment for a ganglion cyst. We also tested the null hypotheses that pain intensity at enrolment, and pain intensity, disability, and satisfaction at final evaluation, are not related to demographic variables, cyst location, choice of treatment, or psychological measures.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: One hundred fifteen patients aged 18 or older with a wrist or finger ganglion cyst presenting to one of three surgeons at a major metropolitan hand surgery practice were invited to participate in a protocol approved by our Human Research Committee. One patient withdrew and 24 could not be contacted within the three attempts allowed per protocol, leaving 90 subjects that completed the protocol.

Informed consent was obtained and patients completed a demographic data sheet, a 10 point ordinal measure of pain intensity, the Pain Catastrophizing Scale (PCS) (Osman et al., 1997; 2000; Sullivan et al., 1995), Center for the Epidemiological Study of Depression (CES-D) instrument (Sheehan et al., 1995; Weissman et al., 1977), and the Pain Anxiety Symptoms Scale (PASS) (McCracken et al., 1992). Patients completed the questionnaires after their initial meeting with the surgeon, during which patients were informed about the nature of the cyst and treatment options.

Per protocol attempts to contact participants were initiated approximately 5 months (between 4 and 7 months) after enrolment. Also per protocol, three attempts at contact were made up to 24 months after enrolment. Upon contact, patients were asked if they elected operative treatment and they completed the Disability of Arm, Shoulder, and Hand questionnaire (DASH) questionnaire (Hudak, 1996), and ordinal measures of pain intensity and satisfaction.

sec.title: Patients
sec.p: Sixty-seven patients (59%) elected non-operative treatment, 23 (20%) operative treatment, and 24 (21%) could not be contacted. Final contact was achieved an average of 10 months (range 4–24 months; median 8 months) after enrolment. Among patients that elected operative treatment, surgery was performed an average of 2 months (median < 1 month) after enrolment. Demographics and patient characteristics are presented in Table 1.

caption.p: Overview of demographic characteristics of the main study cohort (n = 90)

td.bold: Prior surgery for similar condition, n (%)
Other source of bodily pain, n (%)

sec.title: Measures
sec.p: Pain Catastrophizing Scale: The PCS is a reliable and valid measure of negative pain-related cognitions. It has 13 items answered using a four-point Likert scale from “not at all’ (0) to “all of the time” (3).

Center for the Epidemiological Study of Depression Instrument: The CES-D is a reliable, valid, and widely used measure of depression in the general population. It has 20 questions answered using a four-point Likert scale from “rarely or none of the time (< 1 day last week)” (0) to “most or all of the time (5–7 days last week)” (3).
Pain Anxiety Symptoms Scale: The PASS is a reliable and valid measure of anxiety about pain. It has 20 items answered using a six-point Likert scale from “never” (0) to “always” (5).

Disability of Arm, Shoulder, and Hand questionnaire: The DASH is a 30-item disability/symptom scale concerning the patient’s upper-extremity disability during the preceding week. The items are about the degree of difficulty in performing different physical activities because of the arm, shoulder, or hand problem (21 items), severity of each of the symptoms of pain, activity-related pain, tingling, weakness, and stiffness (five items), as well as the problem’s impact on social activities, work, sleep, and self-image (four items). Items are answered using a five-point Likert scale. The scores for all items are then used to calculate a scaled score ranging from 0 (no disability) to 100 (most severe disability).

Pain intensity was measured using a 10-point ordinal scale between 1 (no pain) to 10 (the worst pain ever). Satisfaction was measured using a 10-point ordinal scale between 1 (complete dissatisfaction) to 10 (complete satisfaction).

sec.title: Statistical analyses
sec.p: According to a power calculation based on differences in pain intensity at enrolment among patients electing operative and nonoperative treatment, a sample of 90 patients provides 90% statistical power with alpha 0.05, an effect size of 0.8, and an allocation ratio of 0.33 using the Student’s t-test to determine statistical differences between treatment groups.

In order to determine the most important factors associated with the response variables of treatment choice, pain intensity, disability, and satisfaction while accounting for any confounding (inter-relationship) among explanatory variables, we first looked for differences by comparing each variable with one other variable (bivariate analysis). Any explanatory variables with p < 0.05 in the bivariate analysis were then included in a multivariable statistical analysis that can be used to determine the explanatory variables that account best for the variation in response variables, independent of any confounding among the variables. Care should be taken when interpreting the bivariate analyses separately from the multivariable analyses, as they are subject to the possibility of spurious associations with multiple tests.

For continuous response variables, the bivariate analysis used Pearson correlations for continuous explanatory variables and Student’s t-test and analyses of variance (ANOVA) for categorical variables. Post-hoc analysis of significant differences detected using ANOVA was done using the Tukey test. For dichotomous response variables, we used Student’s t-test and chi-square analyses. Explanatory variables with statistically significant associations in the bivariate analysis (p < 0.05) were entered into multivariable regression analyses. A stepwise backward Wald logistic regression model was constructed to determine factors associated with treatment choice. Stepwise backward multivariable linear regression models were constructed to determine factors associated with the following response variables: pain intensity at enrolment, pain intensity at final evaluation, disability, and satisfaction.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: There were no significant differences in pain intensity at enrolment, demographic, and psychological variables between subjects that elected operative or non-operative treatment or those that were not contacted (p > 0.05) (Table 2). Patients that were not contacted were excluded from further analysis. Final contact was made an average of 8 months after enrolment (range 4–22 months).

caption.p: Results of mean comparisons of important variables between choice of treatment groups in the final study cohort (n = 90) and comparison of differences in means in the main study cohort (n = 114)

fn.p: Final study cohort comparison shows p value of Student t-test and chi-square test.
Main study cohort comparison shows p value of ANOVAs and chi-square test.
CES-D = Center for the Epidemiological Study of Depression; DASH = Disability of Arm, Shoulder and Hand; PASS = Pain Anxiety Symptoms Scale; PCS = Pain Catastrophizing Scale.

sec.p: Among the 90 patients with known treatment status, patients who elected operative treatment were younger (p = 0.02) and less likely to report other pains (p = 0.04; Table 2). In the backwards-stepwise multivariable logistic regression model, younger age was the only predictor of operative treatment (likelihood ratio test = 5.80, OR 0.96, p = 0.02). There was a 4% decrease in chance of electing operative treatment per year gained.

Sixty-six patients (73%) reported scores of 3 or less on pain intensity at enrolment, and 42 (47%) did not report any pain at all. Pain intensity at enrolment correlated with fewer years of education (r = −0.25, p = 0.02), PCS (r = 0.29, p = 0.01), and CES-D (r = 0.26, p = 0.02) (Table 3). The backwards-stepwise multivariable linear regression model included years of education (β = −0.21, p = 0.01) and PCS (β = 0.10, p < 0.01), and explained 13.6% of the variance in pain intensity at enrolment.

fn.p: All significant variables (p < 0.05) in bivariate analysis were entered in the backwards stepwise multivariable linear and logistic regression analyses.
CES-D = Center for Epidemiological Studies Depression; DASH = Disability of Arm, Shoulder and Hand; PCS = Pain Catastrophizing Scale.

sec.p: Seventy-four patients (82%) reported scores of 3 or less on pain intensity at final evaluation, and 54 (60%) did not report any pain at all. Pain intensity at final evaluation correlated with fewer years of education (r = −0.32, p < 0.01) and pain intensity at enrolment (r = 0.31, p < 0.01), but not with choice of treatment. The backwards-stepwise multivariable linear regression model included years of education (β = −0.26, p = 0.02) and pain intensity at enrolment (β = 0.24, p = 0.03) in the final model and explained 13.5% of the variance in pain intensity at final evaluation.

Satisfaction correlated with pain intensity at final evaluation (r = −0.33, p < 0.01), but not with any psychological, demographic, or treatment variables. Disability (DASH scores) correlated significantly with pain intensity at final evaluation (r = 0.51, p < 0.01).

Patients with finger ganglions were older, had less pain at enrolment, lower pain catastrophizing, and greater satisfaction compared with patients with cysts located at the wrist (Table 4). Patients with cysts at the distal interphalangeal joint had less pain than patients with volar wrist ganglions (Table 5).

caption.p: Student t-test analyses of psychosocial variables and age between cyst locations

fn.p: CES-D = Center for the Epidemiological Study of Depression; DASH = Disability of Arm, Shoulder, and Hand; PASS = Pain Anxiety Symptoms Scale; PCS = Pain Catastrophizing Scale.

caption.p: Analyses of variance (ANOVA) of psychosocial variables and age between diagnoses

fn.p: Post-hoc analysis showed a significant difference (p < 0.05).
Post-hoc analysis showed a significant difference (p < 0.01).
Post-hoc analysis of the ANOVA was done using the Tukey test.
CES-D = Center for the Epidemiological Study of Depression; DASH = Disability of Arm, Shoulder, and Hand; PASS = Pain Anxiety Symptoms Scale; PCS = Pain Catastrophizing Scale.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Younger patients are more likely to choose operative treatment for a ganglion cyst. Psychological factors—catastrophic thinking in particular—were associated with pain intensity at enrolment, but not with treatment choice. Operative treatment did not result in lower pain intensity, disability, or higher satisfaction compared with non-operative treatment.

Younger patients are also more likely to choose operative treatment for trapeziometacarpal arthrosis (Lozano-Calderon et al., 2008). It is not clear whether older people are more amenable to reassurance, more adaptive and resilient, or more tolerant of imperfections. In addition, younger patients might be more susceptible to the common cognitive error: “I should have problems when I am older, not now” (Turk and Winter, 2009).

Ganglions are not particularly painful. Nearly 50% of patients in our study reported no pain, and the average pain intensity was around 2 on an 11-point scale. This is consistent with the data of Gude and Morelli (2008), who found that pain is infrequent among patients with ganglion cysts and, when present, is more annoying than disabling. Westbrook et al. (2000) reported 28% of their patients were concerned about malignant growth and few patients seek advice and treatment because of pain. Pain did not predict treatment choice, but was associated with decreased satisfaction and greater disability (Baker et al., 2007). Consequently, patients and surgeons should be cautious when removing a ganglion cyst with the goal of relieving pain.

This study should be interpreted in light of its shortcomings. The setting of this study (an urban east coast tertiary care, academic US teaching hospital) may not be representative of the average patient with a ganglion cyst, although the vast majority of our patients are direct referrals from primary care providers. Also, not all patients with a ganglion come to the doctor, and a fraction are referred to a specialist. Patients completed the questionnaires after they met with the surgeon for their initial evaluation; our approach emphasizes patient education and empowerment, doing all we can to help patients cultivate peace of mind. Hence, the results of this study may underestimate the role of psychological factors as determinants of treatment selection, and may not be generalizable to other orthopaedic departments that have a more traditional biomedical approach. Dias et al. (2007) studied the natural history of dorsal wrist ganglia in the Trent region of England and reported surgery as the preferred treatment strategy at a ratio of three to one, which is the opposite of our patients, of whom only one in five chose operative treatment. Finally, given that psychological factors are important mediators of the relationship between pain and nociception, the fact that pain intensity correlated with final disability and patient satisfaction suggests that psychological factors may play a role that our study was unable to measure.

Future research should address psychological factors such as self-esteem, distorted image, social anxiety, and perfectionism, which have been noted in patients seeking cosmetic procedures (Haas et al., 2008; von Soest et al., 2006). Further research is merited to improve our understanding of patient motivation to seek specialist advice regarding a ganglion cyst and on what basis they choose operative treatment.
